FacilityName: City of Covington Peak Shaving Plant
DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Not regulated per Chemical Safety Information, Site Security and Fuel Relief Act

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Support Activities for Oil and Gas Operations

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The City of Covingtons Peak Shaving Plant, which began operations in 1970, provides gas to supplement the Citys gas distribution system during peak power demands.  Propane is used at the facility and is considered hazardous by the EPA.  Therefore, certain safety precautions are in place in handling propane to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to personal health, and to reduce the threat to the surrounding community.  The facility is owned and operated by the City of Covington.

Worst Case/Alternative Case Releases
The EPA Risk Management Program Guidance Document for Propane Storage Facilities was used for the off site analyses and LandView III was used to estimate population and public receptors.  It should be noted that LandView III uses 1990 census data and the current population will most likely be greater than indicated.
The worst case release scenario is the failure of a 30,000 gallon storage tank, yielding a release of 110,000 lbs. of propane to the atmosphere.  Using the EPA tables, the distance to the endpoint of 1 psi for urban conditions is 0.4 miles.
The alternative or more likely release scenario is a process pipe breaking while pumping.  The EPA Guidance Document (Chapter 2, Table 5) indicates a total release of approximately 6,000 lbs. and a distance to the endpoint of 0.1 miles.

Accident Release Prevention Program
Active environmental, health and safety programs with regards to the safe handling of propane are in place at the plant. The City of Covington complies with all Federal and State regulations as well as the safety procedures outlined in the facilitys Operation and Maintenance Manual.  The plant was constructed in accordance with National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) 59.

Accident History
There has not been an accidental release of propane at the Covington Peak Shaving Plant within the past five years.

Emergency Response Program
The Covington Peak Shaving Plant is included in the communitys emergency respons

e plan.  Response to incidents are handled by the Covington Fire Department.

Planned Safety Changes
The Covington Peak Shaving Plant will continue to provide operator training and periodically review its policies and procedures, but is not planning any major safety changes.  The O & M Manual is currently being updated and revised.
